coredata.dc:title: Non-flammable liquid polymer-in-salt electrolyte enabling secure and dendrite-free lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Tu, Haifeng
Li, Linge
Hu, Yuzhen
Zhang, Yongyi
Wang, Yongjiang
Huang, Wei
Ren, Zhiqiang
Lin, Hongzhen
Liu, Meinan
coredata.dc:description: Lithium-metal batterie (LMB) is regarded as one the most promising high energy battery systems, however the safety concern from lithium dendrites and organic liquid electrolytes seriously impedes its widely application. Herein, a non-flammable liquid “polymer-in-salt” composite electrolyte with superior dendrite-suppression capability is well designed and achieved by using lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) salt, polyethylene glycol dimethyl ether (PEGDME) and 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl-2,2,3,3-tetrafluoropropylether (TTE). Non-flammable TTE used here is on one hand to reduce the high viscosity of this “PEGDME polymer in LiTFSI salt” electrolyte (PISE), and thus enhance its wettability; on the other hand, to maintain the merits of highly contented salt. By taking advantage of these localized highly concentrated lithium salts, aggregated ion clusters are generated in this PISE-TTE system, which construct fast ionic transportation channels, and thus accelerates Li+ transportation. Furthermore, this PISE-TTE electrolyte system interacts with Li anode forming a robust organic/inorganic dual layer solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer. With the assistance of this tough SEI, the optimized PISE0.7-TTE90 exhibits outstanding anti-dendrite growth behavior in Li/Li and Li/Cu cells. Moreover, PISE0.7-TTE90 also delivers an impressive performance in both Li/LiFePO4 (LFP, a capacity of 150 mAh g−1 at 0.5C after 150 cycles) and Li@Cu/LFP (electrochemically deposited Li on Cu current collector, a capacity of 150 mAh g−1 at 0.5C after 50 cycles) cells.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Lithium metal battery
Liquid polymer-in-salt
Non-flammable electrolyte
Organic/inorganic solid electrolyte interface

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Raman spectra of PEGDME, LCE, PISE1.1, PISE0.7, PISE0.7-TTE90, TTE. (b) Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of PISE0.7, TTE, PISE0.7-TTE90. (c-d) RDF of (c) Li-OPEGDME, Li-OTTE, (d) Li–NTFSI − ion pairs in LCE and PISE0.7-TTE90 calculated from MD simulation. (e) Major Li+ coordination structure in LCE and PISE0.7-TTE90 extracted from MD simulation snapshot. Color code: C-dark grey, H-white, O-red, N-blue, F-cyan, S-yellow, Li-purple. (f-g) Schematic of solvation structures of (f) LCE and (g) PISE0.7-TTE90. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

Physicochemical and electrochemical properties of three electrolytes (commercial electrolyte, LCE, PISE0.7-TTE90). (a) Combustion tests. (b) LSV profiles with a potential range of 2.5–6.0 V (vs. Li/Li+) and a scan rate of 10 mV s−1. (c) Ionic conductivity and Li+ transfer number. (d) Arrhenius curves of ionic conductivities.

(a-c) Top-view SEM images of the surface and (d-f) cross-sectional morphologies of Li plated on Cu foils in three electrolyte systems: (a, d) commercial electrolyte, (b, e) LCE, and (c, f) PISE-TTE90. The insets are optical images of the corresponding Li-plated Cu foils with a diameter of 1.0 cm. (g) CE of Li/Cu cells in three electrolyte systems at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 0.5 mAh cm−2. (h) Initial voltage profiles of Li/Cu cells for PISE0.7-TTE90 and commercial electrolyte systems. (i) Long-term cycling performance of Li/Li symmetric cells in three electrolyte systems at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 0.5 mAh cm−2. The insets are magnified voltage profiles of the various cycles. (j) Current profiles of Li/Al cell with PISE0.7-TTE90 electrolyte charged at 4.5 V for 24 h. The insets is a SEM image and its corresponding photographs of the cycled aluminum foil.

(a-c) XPS analysis of the SEI layers on the cycled Li-metal anodes in (a) commercial electrolyte, (b) LCE and (c) PISE0.7-TTE90. (d) The intensity of C2HO− and LiF− in different sputter time. The inset is magnified intensity profiles from 0 s to 60 s. (e-g) The 3D reconstruction of the organic/inorganic SEI dual-layer from PISE0.7-TTE90; C2HO− and LiF−.
(a-b) PDOS obtained by DFT calculations in (a) LCE and (b) PISE0.7-TTE90. (c) Schematic diagrams of the SEI formed on the Li-metal surface in these three electrolyte sytems.

(a) Cycling performance of Li/LFP cells with different electrolytes at 0.5C. (b) Rate capability of Li/LFP cells with PISE0.7-TTE90. (c) Schematic diagram of Li@Cu/LFP cells. (d) Cycling performance of Li@Cu/LFP cells with different electrolytes at 0.5C, and the corresponding charge/discharge curves in (e) PISE0.7-TTE90 and (f) commercial electrolyte.

head.ce:title: Non-flammable liquid polymer-in-salt electrolyte enabling secure and dendrite-free lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Lithium-metal batterie (LMB) is regarded as one the most promising high energy battery systems, however the safety concern from lithium dendrites and organic liquid electrolytes seriously impedes its widely application. Herein, a non-flammable liquid “polymer-in-salt” composite electrolyte with superior dendrite-suppression capability is well designed and achieved by using lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) salt, polyethylene glycol dimethyl ether (PEGDME) and 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl-2,2,3,3-tetrafluoropropylether (TTE). Non-flammable TTE used here is on one hand to reduce the high viscosity of this “PEGDME polymer in LiTFSI salt” electrolyte (PISE), and thus enhance its wettability; on the other hand, to maintain the merits of highly contented salt. By taking advantage of these localized highly concentrated lithium salts, aggregated ion clusters are generated in this PISE-TTE system, which construct fast ionic transportation channels, and thus accelerates Li+ transportation. Furthermore, this PISE-TTE electrolyte system interacts with Li anode forming a robust organic/inorganic dual layer solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer. With the assistance of this tough SEI, the optimized PISE0.7-TTE90 exhibits outstanding anti-dendrite growth behavior in Li/Li and Li/Cu cells. Moreover, PISE0.7-TTE90 also delivers an impressive performance in both Li/LiFePO4 (LFP, a capacity of 150 mAh g−1 at 0.5C after 150 cycles) and Li@Cu/LFP (electrochemically deposited Li on Cu current collector, a capacity of 150 mAh g−1 at 0.5C after 50 cycles) cells.

ce:section.ce:para: With the rapid development of portable devices and electric vehicles, rechargeable batteries with higher energy density are highly demanded [1,2]. Lithium-metal batteries (LMBs) have been regarded as the most promising next generation high-energy secondary batteries due to the high theoretical specific capacity (3860mAh g−1) and the lowest potential (-3.04 V vs the standard hydrogen electrode) of metallic lithium [3]. However, safety issue severely limits the practical application of LMBs [4]. Apart from battery short circuit caused by lithium dendrite, flammable electrolyte systems (either carbonate nor ether) may bring huge disaster in case of leaking [5]. Therefore, exploration and development of safe and efficient electrolyte for LMBs are quite important [6–7].

Recently, polymer electrolyte has attracted great interest because of its superior safety feature [8]. Wang et al developed a heteroatom-based all-fluorinated gel polymer electrolyte showing excellent non-flammability [9]. Liu et al designed a poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP)-based polymer-in-salt electrolyte (PISE) [10]. Although solid polymer electrolytes well address the safety concern, the sluggish ionic diffusion behavior (low ionic conductivity) severely limits their practical application. Researchers make great endeavor to enhance ionic conductivity of polymer electrolyte, such as investigating different polymer chains like polyacrylonitrile (PAN), polyethylene oxide (PEO) to construct PISE [11,12]. Unfortunately, the ionic conductivity of these solid PISE are still unsatisfied, which are much lower than liquid electrolyte systems [11,13]. Considering ionic diffusion via solid polymer could not compete with liquid solvent, the development of nonflammable liquid polymer-based PISE may well address the sluggish kinetics but also maintain superior safety. In 2015, Carbone et al. demonstrated that polyethylene glycol dimethyl ether (PEGDME) with excellent chemical stability, superior thermal stability, environmental benign (non-toxic, non-corrosive) and low cost was a good solvent in LMB system for the improved electrochemical performance [14]. But this PEGDME-based PISE still faces wettability problem caused by superhigh viscosity. Recently, 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl-2,2,3,3-tetrafluoropropylether (TTE) has been intensively studied as an impressive cosolvent for its unique features, including low viscosity, non-flammability, and non-interaction with Li cations [15–17]. The introduction of the TTE diluent not only endows favorable properties with respect to viscosity and wettability but also enables highly effective interphases on the cathode and anode to suppress undesirable side reactions [18]. Consequently, a PEGDME-based PISE assisted by TTE is expected to be an efficient and safe electrolyte in the application of LMBs.

Herein, a liquid polymer-in-salt electrolyte (PISE0.7-TTE90) is designed and fabricated with highly concentrated lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) as salt, PEGDME as solvent and TTE as diluent cosolvent. By taking the advantages of highly concentrated LiTFSI in PEGDME and non-flammable TTE, this PISE-TTE electrolyte exhibits superior properties, such as nonflammability, low viscosity, high ionic conductivity and excellent compability with separator. Moreover, a robust solid electrolyte interface (SEI) composed by organic/inorganic components was constructed, which effectively inhibits the growth of lithium dendrites. As a result, with the assistance of PISE-TTE electrolyte, the coulombic efficiency (CE) of Li/Cu cell is around 96.7% and Li/Li cell can stabilize over 500 h. A high-capacity retention of 150 mAh g−1 after 150 cycles can be achieved in Li/LiFePO4 (LFP) cell. What’s more, even using a self-deposited Li@Cu as the anode, Li@Cu/LiFePO4 cell can still deliver a capacity of 150 mAh g−1 and remain stably around 50 cycles. Both experimental results and computer simulations well demonstrate that this safe and effective PISE0.7-TTE90 electrolyte is promising for the practical application of LMBs.

Lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) (99.9%, Monils Chem Co., Ltd.) was dried at 80 °C for more than 12 h. Molecular sieves were activated at 300 °C for more than 6 h. Polyethylene glycol dimethyl ether (PEGDME, Mn = 400) (99%, Aladdin) and 1,1,2,2,-tetrafluoroethyl-2,2,3,3-tetrafluoropropylether (TTE) (98%, Shanghai Jinghui Industrial Co., Ltd) were dried with the activated molecular sieves for three days before use. Then, LiTFSI with different mass was dissolved in 2.5 mL PEGDME to obtain a series of Li(PEGDME)xTFSI; in which X is the mole fraction of PEGDME/LiTFSI. The composition detail of Li(PEGDME)xTFSI can be found in Table S1. Herein, 1 M LiTFSI in PEGDME is referred as low concentration electrolyte (LCE); while all other Li(PEGDME)xTFSI are referred as “polymer-in-salt” electrolyte (PISEx). To reduce the viscosity of high-concentrated PISE, nonflammable TTE as a dilute solvent is introduced to form PISE-TTEy (y is volume fraction: TTE/PISE + TTE). To well reveal the superior property of PISE-TTE electrolyte system, LCE system and the commercial electrolyte system (1 M LiPF6 dissolving in EC/DMC with 1/1 vol ratio from Duoduo Chem Co. Ltd.) were also investigated as control samples. It should be noted that all the electrolytes were prepared in an argon-filled glove box with H2O and O2 levels ≤ 1 ppm.

The LiFePO4 electrodes were prepared by mixing the active materials LiFePO4 (KEJING STAR Technology Co., Ltd), conductive carbon Super P (KEJING STAR Technology Co., Ltd), and polyvinylidene difluoride binder (5 w% PVDF in N-Methylpyrrolidone, Aladdin) in a weight ratio of 8:1:1. Homogeneous paste was cast onto an aluminum foil and dried at 60 °C for more than 24 h. Finally, the LiFePO4 cathode was punched into disks with 10 mm diameter and the average areal mass loading of LiFePO4 is 2.5 ± 0.3 mg cm−2. With polypropylene (PP) membrane (Celgard 2325) as the separator and lithium metal as the anode, LiFePO4/Li batteries were assembled in CR2025 coin cell.

The AC impedance of coin cells with stainless-steel symmetric electrodes was measured under VMP-300-based Instruments and Boosters (BioLogic). The Ionic conductivity was calculated using the following equation,
(1)
σ =
d
R × S
where σ is the ionic conductivity, d is the thickness of separator and S represents the area of stainless-steel electrode. R is the bulk resistance of the model cell with different electrolytes. A series of σ at different temperatures can be tested and calculated. According to the Arrhenius equation (2), active energy could be calculated to well reveal the kinetic of these electrolyte systems.
(2)

Where Ea, kB , T, σT , are Active energy, Boltzmann constant, temperature, and ionic conductivity at different temperature.

The Li+ transference number (tLi +) is another important parameter, which is deduced using the Bruce-Vincent method [19],
(3)

where ΔV is the applied constant potential (20 mV) during the polarization process, I0 and Iss are the initial and steady-state currents, and R0 and Rss are the initial and steady-state resistance values, respectively.

Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was conducted in Li-steel coin cells, with a potential range of 2.5–6.0 V (vs. Li/Li+) and a scan rate of 10 mV s−1. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) profiles of LiFePO4/Li cells with PISE0.7-TTE10, PISE0.7-TTE50 and PISE0.7-TTE90 were obtained at a range of 2.5–4.0 V and the scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. The electrochemical performance of all the cells were conducted on LAND electrochemical testing system.

Li/Cu and Li/Li cells were assembled and tested using commercial electrolyte, LCE and PISE0.7-TTE90 with a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 and a capacity of 0.5 mA h cm−2. Li@Cu anode was prepared by plating Li onto Cu current collector using commercial electrolyte or PISE0.7-TTE90 with a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 for 6 h.

The electrolyte uptake was calculated using the following equation,
(4,5)
Uptake =
M i
-
M d
M d
× 100 % U p t a k e =
M i
-
M d
S m
Where Mi , Md are the weights of separator immersed into PISE0.7-TTE90 and dry separator, respectively; and Sm is the area of PP separator.

The viscosity of electrolyte was evaluated by Haake RS6000 Rotational Rheometer with P25 CS L rotor at room temperature. Raman spectroscopy (LabRam, HR, Evolution) with 532 nm laser excitation and FTIR spectroscopy (Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700 spectrometer) were used to investigate the solvation structures in different electrolyte. Microstructure of Cu current collector surface and lithium anode surface were studied by a cold-cathode field emission scanning electronic microscopy (SEM, Hitachi, S4800, Japan). Energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) was used to investigate the elemental composition distribution of the lithium anode surface. In addition, the information of solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer was studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha + ), which was conducted on a spectrometer (72 W and 12 kV) with an Al Kα source. The components distribution of SEI layer was further characterized by Time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (IONTOF TOF-SIMS 5–100), which was equipped with a 1 keV Cs+ sputter gun and an electron flood gun for charge neutralization.

Molecular dynamic (MD) simulations were performed using the Forcite package in Materials Studio 2018 software [20]. During the simulation, periodic boundary conditions were applied on LiTFSI/PEGDME/TTE with the molar ratios of 5:20:0 for LCE and 10:6:100 for PISE0.7-TTE90, respectively. The parameters for each interaction are given by the COMPASS force field. All simulations were equilibrant at constant temperature (308 K) and volume (NVT ensemble) for about 20 ns (nanosecond). Atomic coordinates were saved for every 10000 ps (picosecond). The analysis was performed by averaging over the final 1 ns of each trajectory [21,22]. The radial distribution function (RDF) between the Li ions and different functional groups of different molecules in the two systems were calculated. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using DMol3 module in Materials Studio software [13]. Geometry optimization and calculation on projected density of states (PDOS) were performed with the Generalized-Gradient Approximation (GGA)/Perdew-Bruke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional and double numeric polarization (DNP) basis set [23]. The k-point was set as Gamma (1 × 1 × 1). The convergence tolerance was set to be 1.0 × 10−5 Ha, 2.0 × 10−3 Ha Å−1 and 5.0 × 10−3 Å for the energy, maximum force, and maximum displacement, respectively.

High concentrated lithium salt has been confirmed to improve the safety of LMBs [24,25]. Herein, a series of Li(PEGDME)xTFSI (x = 0.7, 0.8, 0.9, 1.0, 1.1) composite electrolytes with high concentration of LiTFSI have been successfully synthesized. Further increasing the concentration of LiTFSI to x = 0.6 causes undissolved LiTFSI in PEGDME solvent due to its oversaturation (Figure S1), therefore, the following discussion about composite electrolytes focuses on x = 0.7–1.1. As listed in Table S1, the concentration of LiTFSI in PEGMDE increases from 3.567 M to 5.606 M with × descending from 1.1 to 0.7. Benefited from high salt concentration, Li(PEGDME)0.7TFSI (referred as PISE0.7) exhibits partly flame-retardancy (Fig. S1a and Video S3), which is attributed to the reduced free PEGDME molecules in this high salt-to-solvent ratio system [24]. Furthermore, PISE0.7 is also expected to present a better electrochemical stability. From the linear sweep voltammetry measurements (LSV), it can be found that PISE0.7 is indeed the most stable one (4.75 V); while other PISE samples can only be stable at a range of 4.3–4.5 V (Fig. S1b), but still better than that of commercial liquid electrolyte (4.23 V). These LSV results suggest that high content LiTFSI can inhibit decomposition of PEGDME solvent under high voltage [20]. To further study these PISE electrolytes, their wetting property and viscosity have been tested, which are also important factors. As shown in Fig. S1c, the contact angel of PISE0.7 is around 92.4°, larger than that of commercial liquid electrolyte (83.4°). Correspondingly, the viscosity of PISE0.7 is the largest (1965 mPa s) among all samples (Table S3), also larger than commercial liquid electrolyte (4.2 mPa s); and its ionic conductivity is the lowest (0.02 mS cm−1), also much lower than that of commercial liquid electrolyte (0.395 mS cm−1, Fig. S1d, e). These results well reveal the tardy electrochemical kinetics in this high content lithium salt electrolyte system, which is hard to apply in practical battery system.

To address the above sluggish ionic transportation issue, an excellent nonflammable TTE solution is adopted here to reduce the viscosity of PISE0.7, and thus improves the ionic conductivity (Fig. S2b,c). As shown in Table S2, a series of different volume ratio of TTE was added into PISE0.7 to form PISE0.7-TTEy (y is the volume ration). It can be found that the ionic conductivity of PISE0.7-TTE is enhanced with the increase of y; and PISE0.7-TTE90 exhibits the highest ionic conductivity of 0.51 mS cm−1 among all PISE0.7-TTE samples (Fig. S2d,e), which is almost 250 times higher than that of PISE0.7 (0.02 mS cm−1). Furthermore, the wettability of PISE0.7-TTE90 also greatly improves as evidenced by small contact angle (28.1°) and the PISE70-TTE90 uptake is 213% and 2.26 mg cm2 (Fig. S2f). Owing to the good electrochemical stability of the TTE, PISE0.7-TTE90 are also oxidation-resistant over 5.01 V versus Li/Li+ (Fig. S2g), implying its excellent features for LMBs. To further investigate the possibility of PISE0.7-TTE90 as a high-performance electrolyte, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiment of Li/LiFePO4 (LFP) cells of PISE0.7-TTE90 was carried out; while PISE0.7-TTE10 and PISE0.7-TTE50 were also studied for comparison. As shown in Fig. S3a, the peak current in CV profiles becomes higher and the voltage difference between oxidation peak and reduction peak becomes smaller with the increase of TTE content, demonstrating the improved reversibility of the battery. Furthermore, the almost overlap CV profiles from different cycles (2–10) again reveal the superior reversibility of Li/LFP battery with the assistance of TTE (Fig. S3b). These experimental results well indicate that the introduction of TTE well improves the kinetics of high content lithium salt electrolyte system.

To well understand the roles of PISE0.7-TTE90 components in improving the electrochemical properties, the interaction between salt and solvent was studied through Raman spectra and Fourier transformation infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). As shown in Fig. 1 a, there are two vibration peaks at 825 and 850 cm−1 in pure PEGDME solvent, corresponding to the CH2 rocking and C-O stretching vibration of PEGDME molecule, respectively [26]. In LCE system (1 M LiTFSI in PEGMDE), it can be observed that a new vibration peak appears at 738 cm−1, indicating the presence of abundant free TFSI− and solvent-separated ion pairs (SSIPs) [27]. With increasing the LiTFSI concentration, the TFSI− peak takes place red shift in PISE1.1 (745 cm−1) and PISE0.7 (750 cm−1), which can be assigned to contact ion pairs (CIPs, TFSI ions interacting with a single Li ion) and aggregated ion pairs (AGGs, TFSI ions interacting with two or more Li ion), respectively [28]. From the fitted results, it can be found that the ratio of AGGs increases from 23.7% to 50.7% with increasing LiTFSI concentration (Fig. S4a), suggesting that unique and fast ion transport channels form in PISE0.7. Interestingly, the ratio of AGGs in PISE0.7-TTE90 is similar, well indicating on coordination between LiTFSI and TTE (Fig. S4b). The peaks centered at 837 and 855 cm−1 can be assigned to the vibration band of TTE in PISE0.7-TTE90 sample, which is the exact same location in pure TTE, again proving no interaction between Li+ and TTE molecule [26]. In addition, FTIR was also used to characterize the TTE solvent, PISE0.7, and PISE0.7-TTE90 (Fig. 1b). In TTE spectra, it can be found a characteristic vibration peak at 1064 cm−1, which is still present in PISE0.7-TTE90 without any shift. The stretching vibration peaks of S=O (at ≈1345 cm−1 and 1191 cm−1) and C-O-C (at ≈989 cm−1) in PISE0.7-TTE90 can also be found in PISE0.7 spectra, again indicating there is no interaction between LiTFSI/PEGDME and TTE [13]. These FTIR results are well consistent with Raman results.

To further reveal the coordination/interaction mechanism between Li+ and PEGDME/TTE/TFSI−, the radial distribution function (RDF) and coordination structures was studied using MD simulations. In Fig. 1c, it can be observed that sharp peak (1.95 Å) appears in LCE RDF curve, which suggests the stronger interaction between Li+ and PEGDMG molecules. The peak intensity of this Li-OPEGDME in PISE0.7-TTE90 system becomes much weaker comparing to that in LCE system, suggesting Li+ is more easily separated from the solvated structure. While there is almost no peak appearing in the Li-OTTE RDF curve, revealing that no coordination of Li+ with TTE solvent [29]. The interaction between Li+ and TFSI− has also been calculated. As shown in Fig. 1d, a broad Li-NTFSI peak at 7.13 Å can be observed in PISE0.7-TTE90 system, indicating the coordination of Li+ with nitrogen atoms in TFSI−, which well matches the results from RDF of Li-OPEGDME in PISE0.7-TTE90 system. In contrast, a tiny peak appears in LCE system, suggesting that only a small amount of nitrogen on TFSI− coordinates with Li+ [30]. The coordination information extracted from MD simulation snapshot (Fig. S5) is summarized in Fig. 1e. In LCE, TFSI− mainly exist in a free state and most Li+ coordinate with PEGDME molecules (Fig. 1f). While in high lithium concentrated PISE0.7-TTE90 system, Li+ coordinate not only with PEGDME, but also with TFSI− forming CIPs and AGGs (Fig. 1g), which are well agreement with the above Raman and FTIR analysis results. All experimental and calculation data well reveal that the superior ionic conductivity of PISE0.7-TTE90 system is contributed by these CIPs and AGGs generated from high concentrated lithium salt; while TTE in this system only plays a role of dilute solvent, which effectively reduce the viscosity of system, and thus boosts the carrier transportation.

Based on the above analysis, PISE0.7-TTE90 is the optimized electrolyte system and it will be used in the following investigation. In order to further examine the advantages of this PISE0.7-TTE90 system, LCE and commercial electrolyte (1 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC) were used here as control samples. As well know, flammability is a key factor to evaluate the safety of electrolyte [4]. A combustion test on these three electrolyte systems were performed. As shown in Fig. 2 a and supplementary videos, the commercial electrolyte and LCE can be easily ignited (Video S1 and S2), suggesting huge risk in practical application; while PISE0.7-TTE90 system could not combust at all (Video S4), demonstrating its superior flame-retardancy and safety. This non-flammable PISE0.7-TTE90 can be contributed by the decrease of free PEGDME molecules from the high salt-to-solvent ratio and the flame-retardant TTE liquid co-solvent.

The electrochemical stability of these three electrolyte systems has been studied by LSV measurement. As shown in Fig. 2b, PISE0.7-TTE90 system can be stable up to 5.01 V, which is much higher than that of LCE (3.98 V) and commercial electrolyte (4.23 V). This high voltage window is contributed by the high content LiTFSI, efficiently inhibiting the decomposition of PEGDME solvent under high voltage; as well as the addition of non-flammable and stable TTE solution.

Ionic conductivity is a key parameter of electrolyte system, since it determines the efficiency of carrier diffusion and transportation [31]. In Fig. 2c and Fig. S6a, it can be found that the ionic conductivity of PISE0.7-TTE90 is around 0.51 mS cm−1 at room temperature, which is two times higher than that of LCE (0.243 mS cm−1), and a bit higher than that of commercial electrolyte (0.395 mS cm−1). The ionic conductivity of PISE0.7-TTE90 rises with temperature increasing (Fig. 2d, S7), indicating its typical Arrhenius behavior. The Ea of PISE0.7-TTE90 is around 0.039 eV, smaller than that of LCE (0.070 eV), a bit larger than that of commercial electrolyte (0.0279 eV), demonstrating its lowest migration barrier for ion transport [15]. In addition, Li+ transference number is another critical parameter to reflect ionic mobilities in electrolytes. The Vincent-Bruce method was used here to evaluate tLi
+ of these three systems [19]. As shown in Fig. 2c and S6b-d, tLi
+ of PISE0.7-TTE90 is calculated to be 0.51, which is much higher than that of LCE (0.26) and commercial electrolyte (0.38). The high tLi
+ of PISE0.7-TTE90 can be attributed to the formed aggregated ionic clusters, which can efficiently restrict the movement of TFSI−, and thus boost transportation of Li+. Based on the above discussion, it can be concluded that PISE0.7-TTE90 electrolyte shows excellent safety and electrochemical stability, as well as high ionic conductivity and lithium mobility.

Considering the above merits, the PISE0.7-TTE90 electrolyte system is expected to achieve the homogenous deposition of lithium, and thus effectively suppress the growth of lithium dendrites among three systems. To verify the above deduction, Li/Cu cells with the three different electrolytes were assembled and tested with a lithium deposition capacity of 3 mA h. As shown in Fig. 3 , numerous lithium dendrites form in Li|commercial electrolyte|Cu system (Fig. 3a,d). The insert photo shows a rough lithium surface, indicating inhomogeneously lithium platting in commercial electrolyte system. According to previous reports [31], these protruding needle-like dendrites can easily penetrate the separator and cause short circuit. In Li|LCE|Cu system, lithium dendrites can still be observed (Fig. 3b,e), but the electrochemically deposited lithium on Cu foil seems more homogeneous than commercial system. However, the side view exposes the loosely platting feature and the thickness of platting layer is around 21 μm which is much thicker than theoretical thickness of 8 μm. Notably, the Li|PISE0.7-TTE90|Cu system illustrates a smooth morphology of platted lithium on Cu foil (Fig. 3c,f) and the thicknesses is around 12 μm, which is much smaller than that of LCE system and close to theoretical value. SEM images and inset photo all demonstrate the homogeneous and dense lithium platting layer on Cu foil, indicating that PISE0.7-TTE90 system indeed restrains the lithium dendrite growth. Corresponding EDS mappings of lithium anodes from Li/Li symmetric cells after 200 cycles in various electrolytes were shown in Fig. S8. Consistent with the above results, PISE-TTE90 system form a uniform and conformal SEI, as evidenced by the homogeneous O signal. Furthermore, the coulombic efficiency (CE) of lithium platting in Li/Cu system using these three electrolytes was investigated. As shown in Fig. 3g, the CE of Li|LCE|Cu cell is very low and it undergoes up and down, which is caused by the strong chemical coordination between PEGDME and Li+, and thus making Li+ hard to be plated and stripped. The CE of Li|PISE0.7-TTE90|Cu cell is around 96.7% and keeps stable along 100 cycles at 0.5 mA cm−2 with an areal capacity of 0.5 mAh cm−2; which is higher than that of commercial system (89.1%), indicating its excellent electrochemical reversibility. Correspondingly, PISE0.7-TTE90 system exhibits lower nucleation and plateau overpotential (28 mV) than that of commercial electrolyte (39 mV), indicating excellent electrochemical kinetics for Li platting in the PISE0.7-TTE90 system (Fig. 3h). The performance of Li|PISE0.7-TTE90|Cu cell at different current density was also studied. As shown in Fig. S9a, it shows a stable cycling performance at 0.25 mA cm−1 and the CE remains around 97% after 300 cycles. Even under a high current density of 1 mA cm−1, Li|PISE0.7-TTE90|Cu cell can still be stable until 71 cycles with CE over 80% (Fig. S9b,c). All these Li/Cu experiments well demonstrate the superior features of PISE0.7-TTE90 electrolyte system in suppressing lithium dendrites. Li/Li symmetric cells were also used to further investigate the electrochemical stability and Li+ stripping/platting kinetics. As shown in Fig. 3i, the voltage of Li|commercial electrolyte|Li cell becomes unstable at 150 h and dramatically decreases at 230 h at operation of 0.5 mA cm−2 and 0.5 mAh cm−2, suggesting the short circuit of cell caused by lithium dendrites. Similarly, Li/Li cell with LCE exhibited rapidly increasing polarization voltage after 250 cycles, implying a significant impedance increase. In contrast, the overpotential of Li|PISE0.7-TTE90|Li cell is around 150 mV and it can stabilize over 500 h; again verifies the excellent property of PISE0.7-TTE90. In a practical battery system, the as-designed electrolyte should be also friendly to Al current collector [20]. Li|PISE0.7-TTE90|Al cell was assembled and charged to 4.5 V for 24 h to investigate whether this electrolyte will corrode Al foil. The smooth surface of Al foil as shown in Fig. 3j well demonstrates no corrosion at all and the PISE0.7-TTE90 electrolyte is good for applying in LMBs.

To clarify the excellent ability on protecting Li anode resulting from PISE0.7-TTE90 electrolyte, the composition of the interface layers from the cycled Li metal surface was investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). In commercial electrolyte system, the interfacial layer formed on Li anode mainly consisted of Li2CO3, LiF, Li2O and O-C=O (Fig. 4 a and S10a,d), contributed from the interfacial reaction among DMC, LiPF6 and Li metal [32]. Unlike carbonate electrolytes, PEGDME-based electrolytes (LCE and PISE0.7-TTE90) contain a higher concentration of ether (C-O) groups, as demonstrated by the higher intensity of the 287–288 eV C 1s peak (Fig. S10b,e) [33]. This clearly indicates that SEI derived from LCE and PISE0.7-TTE90 is enriched in polyether. The noticeable difference between LCE and PISE0.7-TTE90 is that the latter contains more inorganic substances (Fig. 4b,c and S10g.h), such as LiF (684 eV) and Li3N (397 eV), suggesting the multicomponent interface layer [34]. TOF-SIMS results further clearly reveal two-layered structure of SEI formed in PISE0.7-TTE90 system. As shown in Fig. 4d, the intensity signal of C2HO− reaches its maximum at 5 s and then rapidly decay, indicating this organic layer formed at the top of SEI; while the maximum intensity signal value of LiF− is tested at 10 s and then decay smoothly, suggesting LiF forming under C2HO− layer. The corresponding 3D distribution image clearly demonstrate that SEI is composed by C2HO− top layer and LiF bottom layer (Fig. 4e,f,g). This double layer structure with solid and soft substances will well impede the growth of lithium dendrites and prolong lifespan of lithium anode.

To comprehensively understand the interfacial engineering mechanism, the projected density of states (PDOS) of different ions and solvents in the LCE and PISE0.7-TTE90 was calculated by density functional theory (DFT). As shown in Fig. 5 a, comparing with TFSI−, PEGDME shows a lower unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) state in LCE system, therefore, PEGDME takes place some reaction to form polyether substances in the interface layer [21]. A possible reaction mechanism was proposed in Fig. S12. One PEGDME molecule is attacked by electron to form radical PEGDME⋅; and then these PEGDME⋅ take place self-polymerization reactions into a polyether network [35]. Therefore, the interface layer in LCE system mainly consists of organic substance. While in PISE0.7-TTE90 system, TFSI− presents lower LUMO than PEGDME since the high concentrated LiTFSI (Fig. 5b) [36]. Therefore, inorganic substance is firstly formed on the interface layer, and then the polyether would cover on these inorganic substance as second layer, which well matches the multicomponent XPS and TOF-SIMS results. This organic/inorganic dual-layer structured interface not only efficiently suppresses the dendrite growth due to its hardness from inorganic component, but also maintains excellent mechanical stability after cycles benefited from its organic component [37]. In contrast, both commercial electrolyte and LCE system fail to suppress lithium dendrites for cycles. For instance, the only inorganic layer formed in commercial electrolyte system could inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites in beginning, however, it breaks into pieces after several cycles and fails to protect lithium anode continuously [38]. While the as-formed organic layer in LCE system is too soft to suppress these dendrites, and thus also fails to protect lithium anode (Fig. 5c) [39]. Consequently, this multicomponent organic/inorganic dual layer from PISE0.7-TTE90 system contributes to the sustainable lithium platting/stripping due to its promising ionic conductivity and good mechanical property.

To demonstrate the potential use of PISE0.7-TTE90 electrolyte, prototype LMBs were assembled with LiFePO4 (LFP) as cathode and Li metal as the anode. As shown in Fig. 6 a, Li|PISE0.7-TTE90|LFP cell delivers a higher capacity of 150 mAh g−1 after 150 cycles at 0.5C (0.21 mAh cm−2) than that of Li|commercial electrolyte|LFP cell (135 mAh g−1). In addition, the CE drops quickly from 92% (90 cycle) to 80% (150 cycle) in commercial electrolyte system; while it is very stable in the PISE0.7-TTE90 system and the value reaches as high as 99% even after 150 cycles; well demonstrating the efficient robust interface layer and fast Li+ mobility of PISE0.7-TTE90. Except cycle stability, rate performance is another important parameter for practical application. As shown in Fig. 6b, PISE0.7-TTE90 system delivers a specific capacity of 155, 145, 140, 135, 130 mAh g−1 at 0,1C, 0.5C, 1C, 1.5C, 2C, respectively; and the capacity can rise up to140 mAh g−1 when back to 0.5C, indicating the excellent kinetics. Under a charge/discharge rate of 1C, the LMB with PISE0.7-TTE90 also exhibits stable cycling performance with ∼ 90% capacity retention after 120 cycles (Fig. S13a), a high CE of ∼ 99.7% (Fig. S13b) and ignorable polarization voltage (Fig. S13c). To further examine the efficiency of this PISE0.7-TTE90 system, we used electrochemically deposited Li on Cu foil (referred as Li@Cu) as anode to examine the cycle stability of Li@Cu|PISE0.7-TTE90|LFP cell (Fig. 6c). The Li@Cu|commercial electrolyte|LFP cell was also assembled here as comparison. From Fig. 6d, it can be found that PISE0.7-TTE90 system delivers a specific capacity of 150 mAh g−1 at 0.5C, close to the Li anode system; and it keeps stable after 50 cycles. In contrast, the commercial electrolyte system delivers a specific capacity of 100 mAh g−1, lower than its own Li anode system (135 mAh g−1) and PISE0.7-TTE90 system (150 mAh g−1); and further it drops down to 50 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles. Voltage/capacity profiles clearly reveal that the polarization voltage in PISE0.7-TTE90 system (110 mV) is smaller than that in commercial electrolyte system (180 mV), as shown in Fig. 6e,f. Furthermore, PISE0.7-TTE90 system is also compared with other published work and the results are summarized in Table S4. It can be found that PISE0.7-TTE90 shows a higher ionic conductivity (0.51 mS cm−1) than LiTFSI/PVDF-HFP (0.124 mS cm−1), LiTFSI/PEO-LLZO (0.239 mS cm−1), LiTFSI/LiPVFM/PME (0.357 mS cm−1) and LiTFSI/PAN-SiO2 (0.085 mS cm−1) [10,40–42]. Although LiTFSI/PVDF/BPSO-CA system presents higher ionic conductivity (0.78 mS cm−1), its Li/Li battery life (300 cycles at 0.5 mA cm−2) is much shorter than PISE0.7-TTE90 system (500 cycles at 0.5 mA cm−2) [43]. All these results demonstrate that PISE0.7-TTE90 electrolyte are well promising in the application of LMBs.

In summary, a novel liquid PEGDME-TTE electrolyte with high ionic conductivity, good flame retardancy and wide oxidative stability window, has been well designed. This PEGDME-TTE electrolyte greatly improves the performance of LMBs from the following aspects: 1) outstanding thermal stability, the addition of non-flammable TTE effectively enhances the safety of LMBs; 2) wide electrochemical stability voltage window, this PEGDME-TTE system widens the voltage window from 4.2 V to 5.1 V, which makes it suitable to match high voltage cathodes; 3) superior electrochemical kinetics, PEGDME and TTE solvents synergistically endow high ionic conductivity and high lithium transference number, which dramatically improves the performance of LMBs; 4) excellent compatibility with Li anode, high contented Li salt and unique PEGDME solvent contribute to the robust organic/inorganic dual layer SEI, thus efficiently suppressing the growth of lithium dendrites and improving the cycling stability of Li anode. Benefiting from these advantages of PEGDME-TTE electrolyte, Li|PISE0.7-TTE90|LFP cell demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance, i.e., a high specific capacity of 150 mAh g−1 and CE of 99% at 0.5C after 150 cycles. Even using the electrochemically deposited Li as anode, the cell of Li@Cu|PISE0.7-TTE90|LFP can still deliver a high capacity of 150 mAh g−1 at 0.5C and be stable after 50 cycles; which completely beats the commercial electrolyte since its cell capacity drops quickly from 100 to 50 mAh g−1 during 50 cycles. This study provides new insights into the design of the advanced but simple electrolyte system for high energy density LMBs.
